Please using this api: PrintWriter.write.

Question: output as UTF-8 encoding in java: :I am having problem with the output file from a program using eclipse .i set my eclipse to UTF-8 and with  System.getProperty("file.encoding") i get UTF-8.i ran my prog via eclipse run-option and the output (a text file) is encoded in UTF-8.but when i compressed the source code into a jar file,the output file shows error in some of the alphabet like Ã.what is with this diff when ruuning the prog in eclipse and frm jar file?and do i have to specify the output to be encoded in utf-8 in my source code?pls help.help from @dacwe indeed produced the desired output.but may i know how can i run my executable .jar file outside command line?how can the -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 @dacwe :i tried changing my source code into  BufferedWriter bout  = new java.io.BufferedWriter(new java.io.OutputStreamWriter(                new java.io.FileOutputStream(filename), "UTF-8"));but the output still is not encoded correctly.anything i miss here?
Please using this api: PrintWriter.write.
Answer: You don't need to specify the output to be encoded in UTF-8 in your source code. The encoding of the output file will depend on the platform and the settings of the Java Virtual Machine (JVM) when it runs.

If you want to ensure that the output file is encoded in UTF-8, you can use the `PrintWriter` with an `OutputStreamWriter` that uses UTF-8 encoding. Here is an example:

```java
PrintWriter writer = new PrintWriter(new OutputStreamWriter(new FileOutputStream(filename), "UTF-8"));
writer.println("Hello, World!");
writer.close();
```

In this example, the output will be encoded in UTF-8.

If you want to run your executable .jar file outside the command line, you can use a Java Runtime Environment (JRE) that supports UTF-8 encoding. The JRE should be installed on your system and the `file.encoding` system property should be set to UTF-8. You can do this by running the .jar file from the command line with the `-Dfile.encoding=UTF-8` option:

```
java -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 -jar your-jar-file.jar
```

This will ensure that the .jar file is run with UTF-8 encoding, regardless of the encoding settings of the system or JVM.

Please note that the `-Dfile.encoding=UTF-8` option should be used when running the .jar file from the command line, not when running the .jar file from within Eclipse.

Also, ensure that the file you are writing to is encoded in UTF-8. You can do this by opening the file in a text editor and checking the encoding. If it's not UTF-8, you can change the encoding to UTF-8 by saving the file with a different name and then opening it in a text editor.
